g.text: consistent with ionic radii values. The reﬁnement of the
occupation factors resulted in a slight Ca deﬁciency, with Ca/
Ta ratio being 0.89(1). The presence of a minor impurity
phase with main diﬀraction peaks at sin(
was also detected, which may correspond either to
CaO or TaN. A Ca/Ta ratio close to 1 was also inferred from
EDX with distribution of both elements being homogeneous
), while a nitrogen content of 10.5% wt was
determined by combustion analysis which is close (1.82 N per
formula) to that expected for the stoichiometry Ca
These results are consistent with previous ﬁndings by Balbarin
et al. who observed slight calcium deﬁciency and presence of
A. Ca and Ta occupy alternating octahedral sites between
close packed nitrogen slabs. The ordered distribution of
cations within the layers has been reported to be at the origin
The as-prepared sample consists of micrometric aggregates
homogeneous composition, as conﬁrmed by EDX analysis.
from this phase were carried out, both
by chemical oxidation reaction with NO
electrochemical methods. For the electrochemical experiments,
was mixed with conductive Super P carbon in
85:15% wt ratio and subjected to electrochemical oxidation
(de-insertion) tests in Ca metal cells under various conditions.
As no electrochemical activity could be observed at RT,
additional experiments were carried out at moderate temper-
versus capacity proﬁles observed for Ca
C and C/100 rate in Ca three-electrode cell with Ca
reference and counter electrodes, in dry 0.45 MCa(BF
PC 1:1 vol electrolyte. The potential signature displayed is the
measured potential diﬀerence between the working and the
counter electrodes (each measured vs passivated Ca reference).
A full oxidation up to capacity values of about 170 mA h g
reduction limited to lower values of delivered
speciﬁc capacity (i.e. about 0.3 mol of virtually exchange
ions). A plateau centered at about 4.5 V is observed upon
oxidation with high polarization upon further reduction, both
using tape or powder electrodes. A variation of the powder
sample color from dark gray to light brown was detected both
after the chemical and electrochemical oxidation tests,
reasonably suggesting a variation of the tantalum oxidation
(A) Projection of the reﬁned crystal structure of Ca
along the [210] direction. N, Ca, and Ta atoms are represented, respectively,
as orange, magenta, and gray spheres. (B) Backscattered electron SEM image of CaTaN
sample. (C) Characteristic GCPL voltage proﬁles vs
speciﬁc capacity (bottom) and vs moles of virtually de-inserted Ca
of Super P carbon) cells at 100
C and C/100 rate and corresponding ex situ XRD patterns (b,c). (D) X-ray powder diﬀraction patterns of the
pristine (a) and chemically oxidized samples are also displayed in (D). (
